questions.text: Choose the correct statements for cystic fibrosis: Increased Cl-in sweat. Decreased Cl-in sweat. Increased Cl-in pancreatic juice. Decreased Cl-in pancreatic juice. Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

i and iv Cystic fibrosis is a genetic multisystem disease, due to CFTR gene mutation, resulting in inactivation of CFTR chloride channel. There is exocrine & endocrine pancreatic insufficiency. As CFTR protein helps in CL - reabsorption from the sweat, its dysfunction results in increased salt and water secretion as sweat.

Highyeild:

Cystic fibrosis Genetics - Autosomal recessive; defect in CFTR gene on chromosome 7; commonly a deletion of Phe508. Pathophysiology - CFTR encodes an ATP-gated Cl− channel that secretes Cl− in lungs and GI tract, and reabsorbs Cl− in sweat glands. Phe508 deletion causes misfolded protein causing improper protein trafficking and protein retention in RER, protein absent from cell membrane, decreased Cl− (and H2O) secretion; increased intracellular Cl− results in compensatory, increased Na+ reabsorption via epithelial Na+ channels (ENaC), increased H2O reabsorption causing abnormally thick mucus secreted into lungs and GI tract. Increased Na+ reabsorption also causes more negative transepithelial potential difference. Diagnosis - Increased Cl− concentration in pilocarpine-induced sweat test is diagnostic. Can present with contraction alkalosis and hypokalemia (ECF effects analogous to a patient taking a loop diuretic) because of ECF H2O/Na+ losses via sweating and concomitant renal K+/H+ wasting. Increased immunoreactive trypsinogen (newborn screening) due to clogging of pancreatic duct. Complications: Recurrent pulmonary infections (eg, S aureus [infancy and early childhood], P aeruginosa [adulthood], allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis [ABPA]), chronic bronchitis and bronchiectasis causing reticulonodular pattern on CXR, opacification of sinuses. Nasal polyps, nail clubbing. Pancreatic insufficiency, malabsorption with steatorrhea, and fat-soluble vitamin deficiencies (A, D, E, K) progressing to endocrine dysfunction (CF-related diabetes), biliary cirrhosis, liver disease. Meconium ileus in newborns. Infertility in males (absence of vas deferens, spermatogenesis may be unaffected) and subfertility in females (amenorrhea, abnormally thick cervical mucus). Treatment - Multifactorial: chest physiotherapy, albuterol, aerosolized dornase alfa (DNase), and inhaled hypertonic saline facilitate mucus clearance. Azithromycin used as anti-inflammatory agent. Ibuprofen slows disease progression. Pancreatic enzyme replacement therapy (pancrelipase) for pancreatic insufficiency. Combination of lumacaftor or tezacaftor (each corrects misfolded proteins and improves their transport to cell surface) with ivacaftor. (opens Cl– channels causes improved chloride transport).

questions.text: One-day-old term neonate presented with respiratory distress, tachypnea, SpO2-80%, and scaphoid abdomen. Which of the following cannot be used in resuscitation?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Bag and mask ventilation The above clinical scenario is of congenital diaphragmatic hernia. Bag & mask ventilation is contra-indicated in this case as air may enter the stomach & bowel present in thoracic cavity.

Highyeild:

A diaphragmatic hernia is a rare birth defect that occurs when the diaphragm's muscles don't grow together, leaving a hole. This hole allows organs in the abdomen, such as the stomach, intestines, and liver, to move into the thorax. In congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH), the herniation of abdominal contents into the chest cavity most commonly occurs through the foramen of Bochdalek. Hence, CDH is sometimes called Bochdalek's hernia. It is located on the left side of the diaphragm posteriorly. The following common site of herniation is through the foramen of Morgagni, which is anteriorly on the right side. Sigh and symptoms at birth: fast breathing or hard breathing (using extra muscles to help breath) A very flat belly and “barrel shaped” chest cyanosis (bluish color of skin due to low oxygen levels) Bag & mask ventilation is contra-indicated in this case as air may enter the stomach & bowel present in thoracic cavity and this inflation and then cause reduction in space for lung inflation and condition get more worsen. Normal Congenital diaphragmatic hernia.

Solution:

Adolescent HEADSS is a psychiatric screening tool designed for adolescents to address risk behavior.

Highyeild:

The HEADSS assessment is a psychosocial screening tool for adolescents . The acronym stands for: Home, Education, Activities, Drugs, Sex, Suicide The American Academy of Pediatrics (AAP) and other organizations recommend using the HEADSS assessment to address risk behaviors

Table:

#MANTRA HEEADSSS EXAMINATION QUESTIONS Domain Example Question Home Where do you live? How long have you lived there? Who lives with you? Do you have your own room? Education and employment Where do you go to school? What is your favorite/least favorite class? Do you feel safe at school? What are your grades like? Do you have a job? What are your future education/employment plans? Eating Are you concerned about your weight/body changes? Have you ever worried about having food to eat? Activities What do you do for fun? Sports? Reading? Video games? How much TV do you watch in a week? Drugs and alcohol Do any of your friends smoke or drink alcohol? Other drugs? Have you ever tried smoking, alcohol, or drugs with your friends? Sexuality Have you ever dated anyone? Boys, girls, or both? Have you ever kissed anyone? Have you ever had sex? Suicide, depression, and self-harm Have you thought about hurting yourself or someone else? Have you lost interest in things that you used to really enjoy? Safety from injury and violence Do you always wear a seat belt in the car? Have you ever ridden with a driver who was drunk or high? Is there a lot of violence at your school? In your neighborhood? Where you live? Have you ever been picked on or bullied? Have you ever felt you needed to protect yourself?

questions.text: At 6 weeks of life, a child developed fever after DPT vaccination. And now child comes at 10 weeks for the next dose. What should be done next?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Give DPT Vaccination Fevers is a normal part of immune responses. So, a fever after vaccination offers evidence that the child's immune system is responding to the vaccine, and as a result, building immunity against the virus or bacteria that the vaccine targets.

Highyeild:

Short-term, mild reactions to vaccines are common. The Diphtheria, Tetanus, and Pertussis (DTP) vaccine can cause a fever of up to 104°F within 2–3 hours of getting the shot. Other reactions to the DTP vaccine include: Soreness and swelling at the injection site Fussiness Feeling tired Loss of appetite Vomiting More serious reactions, such as seizures, non-stop crying for 3 hours or more, or high fever (over 105°F) happen much less often.

Table:

#MANTRA Vaccine When to give Dose Route Site For pregnant women TT-1 Early in pregnancy 0.5ml Intramuscular Upper arm TT-2 4 weeks after TT-1* 0.5ml Intramuscular Upper arm TT-booster If received 2 TT doses in a pregnancy within last 3 years* 0.5ml Intramuscular Upper arm For infants BCG At birth or as early as possible till one year of age 0.1ml (0.05ml till 1 moth age) Intra dermal Left upper arm Hepatitis At birth or as early as possible within 24 hours 0.5ml Intra muscular Antero lateral side of mid-thigh OPV-0 At birth or as early as possible within 15 days 2 drops Oral Oral OPV-1, 2 & 3 At 6weeks. 10weeks &14 weeks 2 drops Oral Oral DPT 1, 2 & 3 At 6weeks, 10weeks &14 weeks 0.5ml Intramuscular Antero lateral side of mid-thigh Hep B 1, 2 & 3 At 6weeks, 10weeks&14weeks 0.5ml Intramuscular Antero lateral side of mid-thigh Measles 9 completed months-12 months 0.5ml Subcutaneous Right upper arm Vitamin - A (1 st dose) At 9 months with measles Iml (1 lakh IU) Oral Oral For children DPT booster 16-24 month 0.5 ml Intra muscular Antero-lateral side of mid-thigh Measles 2 nd dose 16-24 month 0.5 ml Subcutaneous Right upper arm OPV booster 16-24 month 2 drops Oral Oral Japanese encephalitis ** 16-24 month 0.5ml Subcutaneous Left upper arm Vitamin A*** (2 nd to 9 th dose) 16 months then one dose every 6 month upto age of 5 years 2 ml (2 lakh IU) Oral Oral DPT booster 5-6 years 0.5 ml Intra muscular Upper arm TT 10 years & 16 years 0.5 ml Intra muscular Upper arm

questions.text: A child was brought with history of iron tablet intake. Treatment with deferoxamine is started at what level of serum iron?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

500 mcg/dL Deferoxamine is a parenteral iron chelator which should be administered at serum iron level of about 500 mcg/dl

Highyeild:

Excess iron can be toxic and can lead to serious diseases, including: Liver disease, Heart disease, Diabetes, Hormonal abnormalities, Dysfunctional immune system. Symptoms of iron toxicity include: Black or bloody stools Diarrhea Liver damage Metallic taste in mouth Nausea Vomiting blood Vomiting Abdominal pain Irritability The amount of iron ingested may indicate potential toxicity. Levels between 350 to 500 micrograms/dL are associated with moderate toxicity. Extremely high doses of iron (in the hundreds or thousands of mg) can cause organ failure, coma, convulsions, and death.

Table:

#MANTRA Stages of Iron Toxicity Stage Clinical Effect Time Frame Stage I • GI Irritation 30 min 6 hrs Stage II Latent • Recovery from Gl symptoms 6 hrs 24 hrs Stage III Shock and metabolic acidosis • Metabolic acidosis (anion gap) • Dehydration • Lactic acidosis 6 hrs 72 hrs Stage IV Hepatotoxicity/Hepatic necrosis • Fulminant hepatic failure 12 hrs 96 hrs Stage V Bowel obstruction • GI mucosa healing leads to scarring 2 wks to 8 wks

questions.text: A 3.5 kg term neonate born to a mother with eclampsia, did not cry at birth. Which of the following is the criteria for perinatal asphyxia?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hypotonia Perinatal asphyxia is assess by Cord pH - <7 Apgar score <7 at 1 min Neurological involvement.

Highyeild:

Perinatal asphyxia is an insult to the fetus or newborn due to a lack of oxygen (hypoxia) and/or a lack of perfusion (ischemia) to various organs. It is often associated with tissue lactic acidosis and hypercarbia . The American Academy of Pediatrics (AAP) and the American College of Obstetrics and Gynecology (ACOG) consider the following criteria in diagnosing asphyxia: APGAR score: A score of 0–3 is considered low, 4–6 is moderate, and 7–10 is normal. PNA is diagnosed when the newborn baby does not cry and requires resuscitation, or if the APGAR score at the 5th minute is less than 7. Umbilical artery blood sample: A profound metabolic or mixed acidemia (pH <7.00). Neurological manifestations, g. seizures, coma, hypotonia or hypoxic ischemic encephalopathy (HIE) in the immediate neonatal period. Evidence of multiorgan dysfunction in the immediate neonatal period. Symptoms of birth asphyxia may not be obvious, but the most common symptoms include: Before birth:- abnormal fetal heart rate and low pH levels. At birth:- poor skin color, low heart rate, weak muscle tone, gasping or weak breathing, and meconium stained amniotic fluid. PNA can result in profound systemic and neurologic sequelae due to decreased blood flow and/or oxygen to a fetus or infant during the peripartum period.

questions.text: Mother brings 9 months old child with fever & cough, RR = 48/min, but no chest retraction, what is next step in management?

options.label: A
options.text: Hospitalization of patient with iv antibiotics

options.label: B
options.text: Hospitalize the child and give oral antibiotics

options.label: C
options.text: Send back home with oral medication

questions.explanation:
Solution:

No treatment needed As per the given clinical picture, the child is classified as having NO pneumonia under the IMNCI classification. And can be managed conservatively. The mother should be instructed when to bring the child back.

Highyeild:

IMNCI classification Cough or Difficulty of Breathing SIGNS CLASSIFY AS IDENTIFY TREATMENT ● Any general danger sign or •Chest indrawing or Stridor in a clam child SEVERE PNEUMONIA OR VERY SEVERE DISEASE ● Give first dose of an appropriate antibiotic ● Refer URGENTLY to a hospital Fast breathing PNEUMONIA ● Give an appropriate oral antibiotic for 5days ● Soothe the throat and relieve the cough with a safe remedy ● Advise mother when to return immediately ● Follow-up in 2days No signs of pneumonia or very severe disease NO PNEUMONIA, COUGHOR COLD If coughing 30days refer for assessment ● Soothe the throat and relieve the cough with a safe remedy ● Advise mother when to return immediately ● Follow-up in 6days if not improving

Table:

#MANTRA WHO clinical classification for treatment in children aged 2mo to 5 yr with cough or difficult breathing: Signs, symptoms Classification Therapy Where to treat Cough or cold No fast breathing, chest indrawing or indicators of severe illness No pneumonia Home remedies Home Increased respiratory rate <2 mo-old: 60 per min 2-12 mo-old: 50 per min 12-60 mo-old: 40 per min Pneumonia Cotrimoxazole or amoxicillin Home Chest indrawing Severe pneumonia IV/IM penicillin Hospital Cyanosis, severe chest indrawing, inability to feed Very severe pneumonia IV penicillin gentamicin Hospital

questions.text: Which of the following is not associate with Down’s syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Caudal regression syndrome Caudal regression syndrome is least likely to be seen in down’s syndrome.

Highyeild:

Down syndrome is the most common chromosomal disorder, occurring with a frequency of 1:800 to 1:1000 newborns . Chromosome number 21 is present in triplicate, the origin of the extra chromosome 21 being either maternal or paternal. Down syndrome occurs more often in offspring of mothers conceiving at older age; the risk in the newborn is 1:1550 if maternal age is between 15 and 29 yr, 1:800 at 30-34 yr, 1:270 at 35 to 39 yr, 1:100 at 40 to 44 yr and 1:50 after 45 yrs. Some common physical features of Down syndrome include: A flattened face , especially the bridge of the nose Almond-shaped eyes that slant up A short neck Small ears A tongue that tends to stick out of the mouth Tiny white spots on the iris (colored part) of the eye Small hands and feet Conditions commonly associated with Down syndrome include: Problems with the upper part of the spine Disrupted sleep patterns and sleep disorders Gum disease and dental problems Epilepsy Digestive problems Celiac disease Mental health and emotional problems

questions.text: A 26-year-old patient presents with a history of headache, fever, and neck stiffness for several days. Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis reveals the following parameters: protein 62, glucose 20 mg/dl (plasma glucose 140 mg/dl), and white blood cells composed of lymphocytes. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Tubercular meningitis As per the given clinical findings, the diagnosis is tubercular meningitis.

Highyeild:

Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis Parameter Normal Bacterial Meningitis Viral Meningitis Fungal Meningitis Tuberculous Meningitis Opening pressure (mm H₂O) <180 200-500 NA >250 (Cryptococcus sp) NA WBC count (mm³) 0-5 100-20,000 (mean 800) 5-500 (mean 80) 20-2,000 (mean 100) 5-2,000 (mean 200) WBC differentia No predominance >80% PMN >50% L, <20% PMN >50% L >80% L Protein (mg/dL) 15-50 100-500 30-150 40-150 >50 Glucose (mg/dL) 45-100 (2/3 of serum) <40 (<40% of serum) 30-70 30-70 <40 Gram stain (%+) NA 60-90 - - 37-87 (AFB smear)

questions.text: Which of the following is beneficial in reducing the painful crisis of sickle cell anemia?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hydroxyurea Hydroxyurea increases the level of HbF, decreases the episodes of crisis & transfusion requirement.

Highyeild:

Sickle cell anemia is an autosomal recessive disease that results from the substitution of valine for glutamic acid at position 6 of the beta-globin gene. Patients who are homozygous for the HbS gene have sickle cell disease. Types of Crisis: Vaso-occlusive crisis occurs when the microcirculation is obstructed by sickled red blood cells resulting in ischemic injury . The major complaint is pain, usually affecting bones such as femur, tibia and lower vertebrae. Acute chest syndrome . vaso-occlusive crisis that affects the lung and presents with chest pain, cough, tachypnea, dyspnea, hypoxemia, fever or a new pulmonary infiltrate. Sequestration crisis . This is due to sickled cells that block splenic outflow , leading to the pooling of peripheral blood in the engorged spleen resulting in splenic sequestration . Aplastic crisis . occur when the bone marrow stops producing red blood cells. Hydroxyurea, a myelosuppressive agent, is the only effective drug proven to reduce the frequency of painful episodes . It raises the level of HbF and the hemoglobin level. It usually decreases the rate of painful episodes by 50 % .

questions.text: Which of the following has the least risk of perinatal transmission?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Rubella Rubella has the least risk of perinatal transmission . Rubella or German measles has an intrauterine transmission that causes serious infection in pregnancy which results in abortions or severe fetal defects if infection occurs in the first trimester. The classical triad of congenital rubella syndrome is deafness, cataract, and congenital heart disease.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Herpes simplex infection can be acquired in utero, intrapartum/perinatally, or during the neonatal period. The intrauterine infection causes skin vesicles, eye findings (chorioretinitis, keratoconjunctivitis), and microcephaly/hydra Intrapartum infection presents with either: Skin, eye, and mouth disease Encephalitis Disseminated disease with sepsis-like presentation Option: B. Cytomegalovirus, the most common congenital infection with perinatal transmission presents with hepatosplenomegaly, petechial rashes, jaundice and microcephaly. One of the long-term sequelae is hearing loss. Option: D. Hepatitis B virus is associated with significant perinatal transmission. The most important risk factor that determines perinatal transmission is HBeAg.
